Pet peeve: I hate companies that send you nagging personal reminders, using your first name, and the messages come from no_reply@fuckoff.com.
A related thought -- I'd like to have a site where I could, with one click, send some hate to one of these asshole companies, publicly of course.

Not looking for sandals. Not looking for a boat shoe. Most def not looking for slippers.
It's so weird. I want moccasins. I had a pair a long time ago, and I want them again. I have lots of shoes. I'm actually wearing flipflops right now (someone suggested getting those instead).
I guess people want to post something, and if you give them a reason to, no matter how slender, they go for it.

This is pretty close. 

https://t.co/ta9Gh3qw3S

I wanted something with a thinner sole. It should be kind of a shitty shoe. Cheap. Or maybe it was the wear and tear that made it so.

When I was a teen I had a pair of moccasin-like shoes that I wore without socks everywhere. I want something like that for summer. Shoes w/o socks, I can wear to go shopping. Not for hikes.

Everything I find in search are slippers. 

What should I be searching for?

The insurrection is at Stage 3, following the analogy. If we don't take drastic and perhaps risky steps, we go to Stage 4. 

Remember the treatment for cancer is not without risk too. Chemo can kill you. It certainly won't feel good. But it must be done.
It's like a doctor not warning that cancer, if not treated, will kill you. You might get upset, but that does not relieve the doctor of the responsibility.
To the extent that journalism fails to deliver that message clearly and repeatedly, they are complicit.

Say whatever you want about Trump's supporters, but the truth is Trump is still plotting to overthrow the US government. If we don't defend against that, regardless of what the senators from West Virginia and Arizona think, we deserve to be over.

Trump's insurrection is ongoing. What would you expect, we're not putting up any resistance. And right now, theoretically at least, the resistance occupies the fucking White House. I don't know if Biden understands why he was elected.

I bet our European allies say privately to Biden, we won't begin to trust the US again until you put Trump behind bars. I would if I were them.

However there are no rules about how either JSON or XML are arranged, where the whitespace goes, how indentation works, or even if there is any whitespace or indentation, so it's possible to create totally unreadable data in either format. ;-)

Maybe: JSON is easier to read than XML.

1. JSON is generally arranged as an outline, 

2. JSON generally has more whitespace, better arranged, 

3. XML is more dense, and

4. Lists are easier to read vertically than horizontally.

@binarybits @MediagazerChat Noted that there was no form of writing that would work in the four places I wanted to publish in addition to my blog. 

1. Facebook

2. Twitter

3. Medium

4. Google Reader

Even though GR was long gone in 2017, the rules it imposed on writers were still en force in RSS-land.

@binarybits @MediagazerChat One more thing, the thing that was lost in all this was any hope of interop. Of writing a story on your blog, for example, and cross-posting it where ever people might want to read it. I gave up on trying to do that in 2017.

@radicalbyte They lose devs all the time.
And as soon as they get a chance to bail on you, they will.

It's complete nonsense that it's okay to break users on a "point release" (ie moving from version 3 to r, for example).

Every bit of breakage costs everyone who depends on your product, but ultimately you pay the biggest price.

Next time you want people to update, they won't.

He had already figured out it was a huge mistake. 

He became a member of the No-Breakage School of Software Development.

Font-awesome is also a cautionary tale.

I got to know the founder of the company @davegandy, and as a user I wanted to give him a piece of my mind about how they changed the names of all the icons. 

Why did you have to do that?

This interview with Guido van Rossum about Python 4 also made me think of it. 

https://t.co/jbY5uM9iYw

Python 3 was a breaking release.
Breakage usually shows up in code I haven't worked on in years.
Breakage is so hard to deal with because it comes from things they changed, not things that I changed.

What made me think of it: A note that there's a new version of NPM, a vital utility for Node devs. 

I upgrade when I have no other choice, because my sense is that every time I install a new version, I have breakage.
I think I'm going to have to write a https://t.co/EQXyzynAnM piece about breaking users.
